Articles.Content:
So, I have my first two un-manned but man-capable (Kerbal Kapable?) vessels in orbit of Duna, and it is Year 11, roughly day 100.  I believe the return window I need will come up about day 250 by my rough guestimate, but I would like to know ahead of time (rather than just working Kerbin around to the trailing 75* position) since that might be a busy time with other missions going on.

I use the Transfer Window Planner which tells me the angles for the planets and trajectories, but I don't see that it will pin down the exact day for the transfer window for me.  Can anyone tell me if A) there is a List recorded somewhere of when transfer windows will come up, and B) if I am correct that the Year 11 Return from Duna window will fall at about day 250?

Please note that I am playing stock due to hardware issues and for establishing a performance baseline.

I'm sorry that this doesn't actually answer your question, it's just how I solve similar problems to yours, i.e. "I'm in orbit around Duna, when do I go home?"

  • I use http://ksp.olex.biz to show me how the planets should line up for me to go home.  Just put in origin "Duna", destination "Kerbin", indicate how high the parking orbit above Duna is, and you're good to go.
  • However, that tool only shows you "this is how the planets should be aligned when you depart."  It doesn't tell you "how long will it be until they look like that."
  • I usually solve this by just timewarping in map view until they "look right".
  • However, if you'd like an estimate of how long it'll be before you do the warp:  go look up Duna's synodic period on the KSP wiki entry for Duna.  That's how long Kerbin takes to "lap" Duna, i.e. travel 360 degrees.  So, just visually estimate "how much angle does Kerbin need to gain on Duna", figure out what fraction that is of 360 degrees, multiply by the synodic period, and there's your estimate of how much longer it will be.

Example:  Let's say you go to http://ksp.olex.biz and find that to transfer from Duna to Kerbin, you should leave Duna when Kerbin is 75 degrees behind it.   Suppose that Kerbin is now about 165 degrees behind Duna.  Well, that means that Kerbin needs to gain another 90 degrees on Duna, or 1/4 of a circle.  From the wiki you see that Duna's synodic period with Kerbin is 19645697.3 (why don't they give this in days?), which works out as 909 Kerbin days.  1/4 of that is 227 days.  So that means you'll want to depart about 227 days from now.

Maybe someone else can give you a better answer than the above, that's just how I do it.

Wow- Snark, you told me how to solve it.  A list would be nice (I'm sure NASA can pull a book off a shelf and find transfer windows for the next 50 years), but now I know where to find the data I need to calculate it. Thank you my friend!

2 minutes ago, GarrisonChisholm said:

Wow- Snark, you told me how to solve it.  A list would be nice (I'm sure NASA can pull a book off a shelf and find transfer windows for the next 50 years), but now I know where to find the data I need to calculate it. Thank you my friend!

Glad to be of help. 

Incidentally, "get the synodic period from the wiki" will only help you for trips from Kerbin to another planet or vice versa.  If you're going between two planets and neither one of them is Kerbin, you need to calculate it yourself, so there's a little more button-punching to do.

The synodic period of two planets will be:

Ts = 1 / (1/T1 - 1/T2)

...where T1 and T2 are the orbital periods of the two planets, in whatever time units you like.

For example, if you wanted to know the synodic period of Jool & Dres:

  • Jool's orbital period = 4845 days (from the wiki)
  • Dres' orbital period = 2217 days (also from the wiki)

...so to calculate, take 1/2217 minus 1/4845, then take the reciprocal of that, and you get a synodic period of 4087 days.

Kerbal Alarm Clock has an ( not too accurate) transfer windows alarm, and mechjeb has porkchop plots in one of its interplanetary transfer options. And if you don't want MJ to guide your hand and also create the node, you can at least take a look to see when you have a good transfer window

From https://alexmoon.github.io/ksp/#/Duna/60/Kerbin/80/true/optimal/false/11/100

I have year 11 day 407 for 578 dv

...and Now, I feel particularly ignorant.   I knew about the Alexmoon Launch Window Planner, but hadn't actually bothered to realize it provided Launch Windows to Plan launches. 

 

Thank you Nich!  The lesson learned by embarrassment is a lesson not forgotten...
